item.title: Quezon City to have own molecular laboratory to process COVID-19 tests
item.description: The Quezon City government on Sunday said it is eyeing unveiling on the last week of August its own molecular laboratory that will process COVID-19 tests.

item.title: Jeepney drivers beg for help on Metro Manila's roads amid pandemic
item.description: Jeepney drivers, like millions of others, are out of work after the months-long restrictions crippled the economy, plunging it into recession.

item.title: Protesters pack Belarus capital after Russia says military help available
item.description: Belarusians chanting "Step down!" filled the center of the capital Minsk on Sunday in the biggest protest so far against longtime president Alexander Lukashenko's re-election a week ago after Russia said it would offer him military help if necessary.

item.title: Top Democrats in US Congress call for hearings on mail delays ahead of election
item.description: Top Democrats in the US Congress on Sunday called on President Donald Trump's appointed postmaster general to testify this month on changes that have stoked fears they are aimed at holding up mail-in ballots ahead of the November election.

item.title: DOH: Philippines now has 108 licensed labs for COVID-19 testing
item.description: There are now 108 laboratories nationwide licensed to conduct independent testing for the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) after six more received accreditation, the Department of Health (DOH) said Sunday.

item.title: 540 more health workers catch COVID-19, total up to 6,006
item.description: The Department of Health (DOH) on Sunday reported that 540 more health workers contracted the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) over the past week, raising the total to 6,006 as of August 15.

item.title: Israel-UAE deal a killer for two-state solution --Palestinians
item.description: The agreement between Israel and the United Arab Emirates to normalize ties would kill the two-state solution, strengthen "extremists" and undermine the "possibility of peace," chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat said Sunday.

item.title: Gunmen storm Mogadishu hotel after car bombing; at least 5 dead
item.description: At least five people are dead after gunmen stormed an upscale beachfront hotel in Somalia's capital on Sunday following a car bomb blast outside, in an attack reminiscent of others carried out by Al-Shabaab militants, a police officer and witnesses told AFP.

item.title: PNP s COVID-19 tally rises to 2,919
item.description: There are now 2,919 personnel of the Philippine National Police (PNP) infected with the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) after 77 more tested positive.

item.title: MIAA to investigate overpriced face shields reportedly sold at NAIA
item.description: Manila International Airport Authority (MIAA) General Manager Ed Monreal ordered an investigation on the supposed sale of overpriced face shields at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport as their use was made mandatory in public transportation.

item.title: Ship that oozed oil off Mauritius coast splits in two
item.description: A ship that has leaked more than 1,000 tonnes of oil in pristine waters off the coast of Mauritius has split in two.

item.title: JRRMC to limit emergency room ops from August 19 to 26, 2020
item.description: Emergency room operations of the Jose R. Reyes Memorial Medical Center (JRRMMC) will be limited for a week to give way to the disinfection of the emergency service complex amid the rising cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

item.title: Pasig gov t temporarily waives private school regulatory fees
item.description: The Pasig City government passed an ordinance waiving all regulatory fees for private schools until face-to-face classes are allowed and extended the coverage of its scholarship fund, Mayor Vico Sotto said Sunday.

item.title: Israel expects Bahrain and Oman to follow UAE in formalizing ties
item.description: Bahrain and Oman could be the next Gulf countries to follow the United Arab Emirates in formalizing ties with Israel, Israel's intelligence minister said on Sunday.

item.title: South Korea accuses church pastor as COVID-19 cases surge
item.description: South Korea accused a conservative pastor on Sunday of violating self-isolation rules and obstructing contact tracing at a church where 240 infections have fuelled the country's worst outbreak in over five months.
